He finds him taking some of his possessions into a hut.             *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Francisco... I have to see her                         * before we leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll ask her. Francisco goes into the hut. Hector waits outside, watching the small human dramas all around him. Soon Francisco emerges from the hut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In you go. Hector goes into the hut, stooping low at the small entrance. 125   INT. HUT - DAY                                              125 Ursula is lying in a darkened corner. Hector is shaken by the sight of her, ashen and fevered, but tries not to show it. He kneels beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ursula... it's Hector. She turns her eyes to him but doesn't speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're leaving soon. I've come to say goodbye... Her voice is a whisper. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 125   CONTINUED:                                                       125 URSULA Goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't forget you... I won't forget India... I can't forget how I hurt you... She looks at him but doesn't or cannot speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should have talked... I could have explained... many things... She manages a whispered word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisbon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... I'll pray for you in Lisbon... at the Cathedral... She lies still.       Hector lingers for a moment.   Then he speaks again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry I hurt your pride... Hector has blown it. Ursula pulls herself up on an elbow, finding wells of energy from sheer indignation. Hector is astonished, almost jumping out of his skin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? What did you say?    What are you talking about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing, nothing... Ursula speaks one word, and then falls back into a dead faint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Idiot! She lies still. Hector leans over her to make sure she is still breathing. He whispers nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ursula?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 126   EXT. HUT - DAY                                             126 Outside the hut, Dom Paulo is talking with Francisco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We won't forget you, or what you are doing for these poor people...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not staying here with the intention of dying, Dom Paulo... we'll be following you... when we are fit and well...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and good luck to you...                            * They make what they both know is their final parting.            *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God protect you... it breaks my                        * heart to leave you all here, but I don't know what else I can do. They shake hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're leaving the cross with you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too heavy to   carry... and who knows... it might   make some impression on the   heathens. Hector comes out of the hut, solemn-faced.                       *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Francisco, I must talk to you alone... 127   EXT. HUT - ANOTHER ANGLE - DAY                             127 Hector takes Francisco by the arm and leads him behind the hut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've made your peace with her? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 127   CONTINUED:                                                       127 HECTOR Yes.   I think so...                                      *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank, God... Well, goodbye.                              *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there anything that I can do for you? A letter... a message?                           * Francisco laughs softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... if you were carrying                                * something for me I would have to worry about you... if you go empty-handed I can put you out of my mind! Hector smiles uncertainly, unsure if Francisco is making a joke. Then he becomes more serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to ask you something.                              * There's no easy way to do it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, Hector...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your boots... Francisco looks down at his boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I have them? You can have mine... they'll be fine for here... but I have to walk six hundred miles... Hector lifts a foot to show Francisco his boot. Francisco is stunned into silence. But then a smile comes to his                 * face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you're right... I daresay                            * my boots would take you six hundred                       * miles... I look after them... Hector becomes almost poetic in his pleading. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 127   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll walk all the way home, Francisco... I'll pray for your soul in the Cathedral in Lisbon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... In my boots...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Francisco starts to laugh out loud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector, you have surpassed yourself... sit down and take my boots! Francisco starts to take off his boots. Hector does the             * same. He can't believe his luck. At this moment, he                 * loves Francisco. He makes nonsensical small talk, hopping around on one foot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They were made by Da Fosca, weren't they? Francisco is giggling now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The best bootmaker in Goa... pray for my soul in Lisbon, Hector... and pray for your own... Francisco is laughing, but Hector doesn't get the joke. * 128   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                             128 A different forest. A wilderness of giant pines, ranging through the mountains for hundred of miles. It is late              * in the year. There is one human sound in the cold still-            * ness, a voice singing. BOBBY, the owner of the voice, has a pack on his back.              * He is making his way up a steep slope to an area of flat ground. He stops singing, looks around, and calls out               * in a powerful voice.                                                *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've gone... long gone! Bobby looks around the abandoned camp, the dead fires,              * cleared areas for tents. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 128   CONTINUED:                                                     128 Up the slope and INTO VIEW comes his companion, leading a laden pack horse. It is Hector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've been gone a week, at least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're ten days late... They look at each other.      They are in trouble, and now they know it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheer up. Have a look around. I'll start on a fire... 129   EXT. CAMPSITE - DAY                                           129 Hector has scoured the campsite.      He holds up a canteen he has found.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Sandy's... whiskey...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well done, my lad! Hector walks to the fire, pleased with     himself. Bobby unfolds his fist and looks at what he     has found, an Indian arrowhead with a few inches of     broken shaft. He folds his hand over it again, keeping     his secret. Behind them, nailed to a tree, is a plaque their companions have left. It reads, "Pennsylvania Boundary Expedition 1761, Marker 152." Also on the plaque someone has written, "We left here, 20th October." 130   EXT. CAMP - NIGHT                                             130 Hector and Bobby sit by the fire with their supper.      They are both anxious, but pretend not to be. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 130   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even if we lose their track, we'll still hit the river... we can't miss that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too high for Indians?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much too high. You won't find an Indian up here. We just have to keep our heads... no panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you did find an Indian, what would he be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wouldn't... but he might be a Delaware if you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We keep working?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not. We can log the peaks on the far side, just a couple of sightings a day... keep us busy... Their forced tone of matter-of-factness only serves to heighten the growing feeling of doom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think we'll get out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If we keep our heads.   I wish I had some tobacco. 131   EXT. CAMP - ANOTHER ANGLE - NIGHT                        131 Hector is lying awake, watching Bobby's sleeping form on the ground at the other side of the dying fire. Behind Bobby is a wolf, sniffing and edging his way closer to them. Hector isn't anxious. He knows the wolf will soon become aware of them and move off. He is worried about something else. From under the pack that makes his pillow he pulls a piece of broken arrow, a shaft and some feathers, the other end of Bobby's find. He looks at it, then looks back to Bobby and the wolf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 132   EXT. CAMP - MORNING                                        132 In the morning Hector and Bobby are taking readings from the instruments they have hung on a large tree, main- taining the disciplines of their work. It gives some shape and meaning to their predicament.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barometer... twenty-eight and three-eighths... temperature...                        * low... thirty-four... high... forty-two and a half... time... Hector writes it in the log book. Bobby goes to the              * horse and takes a brass chronometer from a box strapped to the saddle. Hector takes out a smaller chronometer from his own pack. They compare readings. There is a difference of some four or five minutes in the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's getting worse... you're nearly five minutes fast now...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not fast... you're slowing down. They obviously have this tiff every morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the point of having two chronometers when you don't take the average?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly... you should throw yours away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're unscientific, Bobby... at heart... Hector writes in the book.   He speaks pointedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven twenty-five... Bobby mocks him with a laugh.                                    * 133   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                          133 Bobby is leading the horse and Hector walks on ahead.            * The going is easy through the ferns and grasses. Bobby           * for a moment forgets his apprehensions and starts to sing loudly. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 133   CONTINUED:                                                    133 BOBBY I see her in the dewy flowers I see her sweet and fair... His voice rings sharply around the forest. Hector far ahead turns around, taken by surprise. Bobby has frightened himself too. He eyes the forest all around as the echo of his voice fades. Chastened, he begins to sing again, quietly this time, under his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's not a bonny bird that sings But minds me o' my Jean... 134   EXT. CLEARING - DAY                                        134 Hector and Bobby have stopped at a point of bare rock looking out across the broad valley. They are building a pile of stones, a cairn. They work quietly, methodically. The only sounds are of their breathing and the CLICK-CLACK of the stones. We feel the echoes of our many previous Hectors and their piles of stones, built for this or that purpose. Our doomed surveyors are acting out the same ritual, this time in the name of science. They finish the cairn and erect their heavy tripod over it, and dangle a plumb line from the tripod. Bobby scratches the center point on the top stone of the cairn. They are establishing a survey point. They talk as they work. When they anchor their   tripod, the cold hard sound of their CHISELS STRIKING   ROCK ECHOES all through the forest. It unnerves them. They    stop hammering and listen to the ECHO BOUNCING down the   valley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure this is a good idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get out of here. They hastily dismantle the equipment and load up the horse, in an atmosphere of controlled panic. 135   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                          135 They are travelling together now, on either side of the horse's nose, finding comfort in the closeness of each other. They stop for Bobby to consult his compass. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 135   CONTINUED:                                                       135 He indicates a slight change of direction, and they move off again. Still they don't talk. We can feel their anxiety breeding in the silence. Why don't they talk? They proceed in this weighty silence, but even the CRIES of the BIRDS now seem to mock them. The route takes them downhill. The slopes are more dense with undergrowth now and the going isn't so easy. Some- times they are reduced to an undignified scramble, hanging onto the bulk of the horse between them. They no longer look much like conquerors of the wilderness. 136   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                            136 They are on the valley floor now. The trees are more openly spaced and the grass is richer. They are moving quickly but they have a hard time keeping the horse on the trot. It hasn't seen grass this good in weeks. 137   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                            137 They are moving more slowly, the ground is rockier and the trees are thickening. They take the easy way up the hillside, a natural path made by deer or bear. It is difficult to know who is more shaken by their encounter, the Indian or Hector and Bobby. The INDIAN is sitting behind a tree as they pass, dozing or deep in reverie. They almost pass without noticing him, but Hector gives a turn of his head and there is the Indian four feet from him. At the same instant the Indian comes to his senses and sits bolt upright. The encounter is high comedy but full of terror for all of them. The Indian stands up.       Hector absurdly greets him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi!   Hello! The Indian backs off from them, holding his hands up and smiling crazily, as if to say, "Don't mind me, boys, I'm just leaving..." Hector and Bobby are equally silly in their response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, come back... we're just moving through... don't apologize... we all got a fright... goodbye... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 137   CONTINUED:                                                       137 The Indian is in full retreat now, waving his hands about apologetically, but making good distance from them. Suddenly, he is gone. It has happened so quickly that Hector and Bobby scarcely believe it has happened. Then they realize that in their fright they have let go of the horse. It has headed back down to the tastier pastures in the valley. They see it disappearing into the trees below them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was stupid...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you see him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure I saw him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was he a Delaware?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How the fuck should I know? He was an Indian... and Indians don't come in ones...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... I think he was an Indian too... What about the horse?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going back down there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't panic, Bobby...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? He runs off into the forest.        Then he turns and shouts to Hector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on! Hector follows him, a mad race through the forest. 138   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                             138 Hector and Bobby are sitting on a rock, gathering their wits. It is odd how they talk so matter-of-factly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you see? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 138   CONTINUED:                                                    138 BOBBY Same as you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An Indian... with long hair...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it... kind of short...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... he was't tall...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the one. Hector scans the hills above them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get a bit further up. They move off.     Bobby looks at Hector's backpack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What've you got in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some food, the logbooks, my letters, a candle...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. 139   EXT. CAMP - DAY                                        139 They have stopped to make camp. It is late afternoon, the sky just darkening, sharp shadows on the far peaks, a purple glow in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We won't have a fire tonight. We should make a shelter though, in case it snows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about bears, without a fire? Bobby laughs quietly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't even think about bears, Hector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 140   EXT. CAMP - NIGHT                                          140 They are making a round frame of bent branches and cover- ing it with foliage. Half-hidden in the undergrowth, it is big enough for two men to huddle in. Tonight they feel the most basic of urges, to curl up in a ball and hide. 141   INT. CAMP - NIGHT                                          141 They are safe and snug in their hideaway. Hector has lit his candle. He is reading his letters, holding them close to his eyes in the dimness. He has the air of someone putting his affairs in order. Bobby is thinking aloud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe he's lost too... on his own... must be Delaware... they were chased up here years ago... everybody thought they'd cleared off west... the other side of Ohio... they were an angry lot... no wonder... they used to farm on the coast. He looks up at Hector, and allows himself a small smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, read it out... Hector looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?     No... not tonight...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've had to listen to it every night since April... why not now? Hector gives in. He holds a scrap of paper close to the candle and reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear, Father, I miss you. Three frogs are dead. Everybody misses you.  Bring me a bear's head and claws and a gun. School is good. Miss White has married a fireman. Come back soon. Do not worry about the frogs, they did not have names. Nathaniel. Hector looks up at Bobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not so funny now as it was. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 141   CONTINUED:                                                     141 BOBBY It wasn't funny then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you knew him... if you could picture him saying it... it would be funnier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a father like you... nine months on a whaler and then three weeks at home telling us all how much he missed us...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going home, for the winter... Bobby doesn't pursue his argument.    He tenses, then sniffs the air vigorously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smell it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddam it... smell it? Hector sniffs some more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tobacco? They whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the hell is it coming from? He puts his head out of the shelter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't tell... a night like this it could carry for miles... He huddles back inside the shelter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I had a smoke. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 141   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a tense silence, Hector takes a small package from an inside pocket. He hands it to Bobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was saving it... you have it... It is a wedge of tobacco.      Bobby takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, you were saving it? You know the rules... no hoarding, tobacco or food... you've listened to me for a month, day and night... wanting a smoke...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well have it now... I don't smoke... take it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've kept it from me, and you don't even use it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was saving it for my birthday... I was going to give it to you then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to wait until your birthday for a smoke? Who are you... the fucking king?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, smoke it... have it now...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bloody won't... I'm not smoking on your command... I bloody won't. There is a brooding silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God,   your poor children... what do they   have to do for a piece of candy   in your house? It's very hard   to like you sometimes... d'you know   that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, Bobby... but that's how I feel about you, too... that's why we're friends... we try hard... come on... smoke your pipe... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 141   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector is neatly turning the tables on Bobby, who now appears churlish, childish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... I'll have it in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on... tell me... who would you rather be sitting here with... have a think... Bobby does, and then breaks into a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daniel Boone? Hector smiles, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. He would be a help... but after Daniel Boone...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't think of anyone else... but you're impossible to like sometimes. Suddenly Bobby grows shy of their growing intimacy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should sleep. We've got a lot of running to do in the morning. But Hector has other plans.          He is in control of their friendship now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No we're not... we're going to talk... all night... Bobby yields to this with the softest, most vulnerable smile we have yet seen on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... where do you want to start? Bobby is silent, but still smiles his acquiescent smile. Hector reads the silence well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know where you want to start... Bobby is still silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alicia... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 141   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobby's smile breaks into a boyish laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... what about Alicia?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... I'm sorry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, you're sorry... I'm the one that has to apologize... Bobby is mischievous now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no you're not... It will be a worthwhile night for both of them. 142   EXT. FOREST - DAWN                                          142 It is a glorious dawn. Bobby sits looking out on the valley, smoking his pipe. Behind him Hector is busy writing in his log book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it a beautiful day? Hector finishes his writing, tears out the page from his book. He offers it to Bobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've said who we are and where we're headed. Want to sign it, write anything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The peak we logged yesterday... I've named it Nathanial Mountain. After my boy... is that fine with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was going to call it Tobacco Mountain... or Mount Alicia... but Nathaniel's fine... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 142   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector smiles. He puts the paper in a small leather pouch, puts the pouch on the ground near the shelter, and starts to build a small pile of protective stones on top of it. Bobby stands, and turns to watch him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's get away from here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: North?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.    Keep the sun on our backs. Bobby walks off with great clouds of tobacco smoke billowing defiantly around him, as if to challenge their night-time tormentor. Hector takes a last look at their shelter and its little memorial cairn and then runs to catch up with Bobby. 143   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                          143 Hector and Bobby look vulnerable as they walk through the open forest with their meager packs on their backs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can move quicker without the horse... we just have to keep moving... we have to get away from here. Behind them they don't see the figure moving from the cover of one tree to another, and then another figure following the first. They move like ghosts. 144   EXT. FOREST - DAY                                          144 Bobby is a few steps ahead of Hector. He dips down over a rise, and instantly returns. He throws himself and Hector to the ground. Hector tries to struggle free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quiet.   They're on the other side... Hector ducks lower, hugging the ground. Bobby is already sliding up the slope to look over the rise. Hector follows him. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 144   CONTINUED:                                                    144 On the other side, they see the women and children of a small group of Indians at the edge of a stream. The women are washing clothes, the children are splashing and playing. We are close enough to hear their laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're right in the middle of them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it have to be bad?   They might be friendly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They were chased here... They should be on the coast growing corn... Bobby turns to Hector to make his point. That is when he sees the first of the figures, just the ghost of a shadow moving from tree to rock. His eyes flick across the forest behind them. He sees another figure caught in the act of seeking cover, looking absurdly embarrassed for the fleeting moment that we see it. Then Bobby sees another. Are they teasing them? It looks so much like a game children would play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh-oh...                                               *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong?                                          *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're behind us. They must think we're stalking the women... Hector looks and sees nothing. Fifty Indians hold their breath. The forest seems empty. But Hector looks at Bobby. He is grey-faced, a man who is looking at death. Hector knows they are doomed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to run?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll do what you do. * They leap to their feet and run. There is only one way to go, over the rise, through the women and children and across the stream. To the watching Indians it looks like a direct attack on their families. From behind trees and rocks they emerge and begin the chase. A tragedy of misunderstanding. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 144   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector and Bobby scatter the women and children and splash across the stream, burning all their energy in               * this mad life-or-death race. Although their families are safe, the Indians keep up the chase, the moment of confusion compounded in action. They lope easily after them, waiting for the white men to tire. There are no               * whoops or shouts. They follow Hector and Bobby into the trees, spreading out on either side, shaping the human net that will soon engulf them. It is a menacing spectacle. Death is near.        Hector and Bobby stay close together as they run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When they catch up... fight... it'll be quicker... fight like hell...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're not going to catch us. We're going home. Hector stretches out an arm to Bobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold my hand, Bobby... They hold hands and run. 145   EXT. BUILDING - DAY                                           145 A war party of media people surround Hector as he exits a Yellow Cab. He forces his way through the yelling crowd of REPORTERS and camera crews. Hector is trying to make his way into a crumbling apartment building in Queens. Policemen help Hector through the barrage of                * shouted questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know the lady, Mr. Troup?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think you'll go to jail again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look here for a second, will you, Mr. Troup?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you talk to us when you come out? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 145   CONTINUED:                                                    145 Hector enters the building. The media mob immediately switch off their energy. They light cigarettes, fiddle              * with cameras, stare into space, as if someone has shouted "Cut." 146   INT. BUILDING - DAY                                         146 Hector climbs to the fourth floor.     A POLICEMAN goes with him. Two paramedics come up the stairs behind them, carrying a stretcher. The Policeman stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You guys are downstairs... third floor... thirty-eight... The paramedics turn around and head back down the stairs. Hector looks at the Policeman curiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're forty-eight. They continue climbing. 147   INT. APARTMENT - DAY                                        147 Hector and the Policeman squeeze past a cluster of people at the door and enter the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Troup! A DETECTIVE is with another man who looks like a city official.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come here, Troup. I'm Cobb. Hector joins them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bring everything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Building warrant, license, fire certificate, sanitation certificate... I want them all... This is Mr. Santiago, from the city... insurance... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 147   CONTINUED:                                                      147 HECTOR This isn't really my building... it's my partner's... I just took the call and came right over... I have to leave town in an hour                          * or so anyway...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slow down, Troup... so it's 3:15 on a Friday... you're staying here 'til Mr. Santiago gets the paperwork... get your partner over here, with everything... this is serious... Hector looks at his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might have to close the place down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is she? The Detective and Hector walk down the hall. They stop at the door of the bathroom. Hector looks inside. There is a large ragged hole in the floor. At the far side of it the toilet unit dangles at a dangerous angle into the hole, held only by its plumbing. Firemen are working to secure it and what is left of the floor with metal props and hydraulic jacks. Lying on the floor below, surrounded by rubble, and being attended by the paramedics, is an old lady, MRS. PHILIPPOPOLIS. She tries to sit up when she sees Hector peering at her over the rim of the hole. She looks angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I phoned you Monday... I told you the floor was making noises...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not me, Mrs. Philippopolis... my ex-partner... I think you spoke                          * to him... How are you feeling? Hector says this clearly, for the benefit of the Detective and Mr. Santiago. The Detecitve is unimpressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back from there, Troup, the floor's still moving... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 147   CONTINUED:     (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll make a couple of calls... I'll straighten it out... is she bad? Why don't they move her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They waited for a portable X-Ray machine... they can move her now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She seems in good spirits... As if in response, Mrs. Philippopolis shouts up to Hector as she sees him leaving the bathroom above her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait 'til my son sees his mother lying here like this... he's gonna sue you... you're a lousy landlord... you should be ashamed... to let old people live like this... I phoned you Monday... I have a witness! I was dancing with a prince on my eighteenth birthday, and now look at me... you have me falling down a toilet! 148   INT. BUILDING - DAY                                         148 Hector retreats into the hallway. Takes out his mobile phone and dials, while watching the ominous Mr. Santiago making copius notes in his book. Hector gets connected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boris... why did you do this to me? Get down here now... they want all kinds of certificates... They won't let me leave the building... I have my kids tonight, I haven't seen them in four years... I did tell you, I've been talking about it all week... how come they phoned me, this isn't my building? What? Don't tell me anymore... I want you here, now... and on your knee... I'll phone the lawyer... but you move. My weekend's ruined before it's started. Hector quickly dials another number. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 148   CONTINUED:                                                    148 HECTOR Anna... thank God... you have to help me... I'm still in Queens...                      * I've got cops here and everything                      * ... I need your car... I don't have time to pick up the rental now... they won't let me leave the building... you come down here... and put my bag in the car... no..                      * I have to pick the kids up by six, otherwise I fuck up her weekend too... she'll kill me... this is an emergency... what can I say? Please... right... okay... He finishes the call just as Santiago approaches, waving his notebook now full of incriminating notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It looks like water rotted the floor... You have any plumbing maintenance records?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the office... I might have some bills... it's not my building.                         * Santiago is talking almost to himself now, absorbed in the mundane mechanics of Hector's building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a weird one... I don't know how water could sit in there for so long without somebody noticing ... you didn't use water-resistent paint on the ceilings did you? Hector shakes his head wearily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't really know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to have to check out                      * the whole building... you know that, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I do it Monday?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good joke... it'll take you a month. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 148   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector is already dialing another number as Santiago wanders off in search of further fascinating discoveries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I speak with Leonard, please... Mr. Deutsch? My name is Hector Troup, Borlonski and Troup, Real Estate... There is a moment's pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leonard... it's Hector... Borlonski and Troup... yes... listen, we've had a domestic accident at our Eighth Street building... a floor                     * ... and an old lady... she did mention the word sue, but it might have been hysterics... what I need to know is what certificates you have on file for the building... I                    * know it's Friday... just do one                       * thing... let me know if the insurance is current... I need to know that... I'm on my mobile... anything you have... before five ... thank you... During the call Hector has walked   down the hall and back to the hole in the floor. He sees    Mrs. Philippopolis, now strapped in a stretcher, being   carried out of the room below. At the sight of him,    she tries to sit up, straining on her straps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My son's downstairs... when he sees me like this he'll kill you... go on... jump through the hole... see what it feels like! Break both legs! Hector is almost tempted to do what she says. 149   INT. BUILDING - ANOTHER ANGLE - DAY                          149 Hector is following the paramedics as they negotiate Mrs. Philippopolis down the three flights of stairs. He is on the phone again. This time to his former wife. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 149   CONTINUED:                                                      149 HECTOR I'll be on the way in thirty minutes at the outside... I can't say... Queens to New Jersey, on a Friday... what do you think? I'll be there... it's important to me too, I've been trying to put this weekend together for years... I'll be there... I won't take it out on the kids, I can walk away from problems... as soon as I get the car... I'll be there... All the while Mrs. Philippopolis issues a non-stop                    * torrent of Greek expletives -- calmly and in a considered             * tone, but obviously obscene. Hector is shocked.                       * 150   EXT. BUILDING - DAY                                           150 On a street Hector stands with a Policeman watching                   * Mrs. Philippopolis being loaded into the ambulance. Her SON is with her. When she is safely inside he walks towards Hector. Fortunately he is of modest build, and a head shorter than Hector, and he seems to be saving his wrath for the Courthouse.

direction.raw_text: Mr. Troup, I'm George Philippopolis. They shake hands.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... it's happened... you want to travel with us, or do you have a car?

direction.raw_text: To the hospital...

direction.raw_text: Well, I wasn't planning to...

direction.raw_text: You're not making a visit to the hospital? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 150   CONTINUED:                                                      150 HECTOR I've talked to your mother, given her my best wishes... she wants her family with her now... Any other Friday but this one. The Son addresses the Policeman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not coming to the hospital... The Policeman looks at Hector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That could look bad... The cop is enjoying his role as straight man to these two. Hector takes out his diary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, George... here's what I can do... I'll visit her on Tuesday, I'll organize some flowers... lots...                                                  *
direction.name: direction
