direction.raw_text: They won't let me leave here... The Policeman this time backs him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's true. The Son backs off to the waiting ambulance reluctantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait 'til they hear this in court                        * ... he wouldn't even make a trip                         * to the hospital... Can't you even                        * give me a credit card number?                            * 151   EXT. BUILDING - ANOTHER ANGLE - DAY                            151 The ambulance drives off just as BORIS arrives.       Hector runs to the car. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 151   CONTINUED:                                                      151 HECTOR It's never been this bad, Boris. Deutsch is checking the insurance... did you bring the rest?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... we're covered for most things... the license is current, the inspection certificate is okay...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's with the we... it's your problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a witch... her   bones must be made of steel... she   didn't break a thing... it might   help if you make a visit to the   hospital... why did you do this   to me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Hector... I   just put your name on the lousy   forms... I didn't plan this... I   just borrowed your name on   the titles. Hector doesn't let up on his anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you to stop doing that... why does this keep happening to me... my name is mine... use your own name, Boris Borlonski... will you remember that? Boris Borlonski! Boris is conciliatory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hector... forgive me... I'll take care of it... don't let it spoil your weekend... four years, huh? You make the most of it... and don't worry, you'll walk away from this... I'm sorry... Hector is calm now. We can sense real depth in their relationship, despite Boris's pranks. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 151   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I'm sorry too... you have to get out of this business... I thought I had...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on... have a great weekend... I'll talk to you on Monday... we'll straighten everything out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the worst it's been.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything can be fixed... always. Then Hector's girl friend ANNA arrives in her car. It is a bright pink station wagon, highly decorated with flower motifs and slogans like "ANNA'S ARRANGEMENTS," and "FRESH OR DRY, WE'LL PLEASE THE EYE." Anna is a florist. Hector brightens when he sees her. Everything is falling into place. All he has to do now is cross two rivers and Manhatan Island in under an hour, in Anna's pink car. He runs to meet her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get in... you can dropp me at the shop. Hector gets into the car, smiling broadly. 152   INT. CAR - DAY                                                152 Anna drives skilfully through the busy Friday streets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bring my bag?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. Your camera's in there too. Take some photographs of the kids...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.   Thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nervous? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 152   CONTINUED:                                                      152 HECTOR Not much... just like I'm being executed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well you deserve to suffer. Our Hectors have been hearing this for centuries, but at least Anna smiles when she says it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry... this is the beginning of something... not the end... you can start being a father again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad you talked me into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't do much... you were ready...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right... you're absolutely right... I was ready... I am ready, for everything... I'm fixing all that shit with Boris... I told him... it can't go on... I want my freedom. Anna is looking at him amusedly, nodding her head with every earnest pronouncement that he makes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and the kids... that'll work out... we can have them over sometimes... Yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure... that was the plan... when we have the space...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, when we have the space... when we get the bigger apartment... together...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There you go... you said it... the bigger apartment together... Hector is pleased with himself. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 152   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... I said it, didn't I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a man of decision, Hector... Hector is high on his optimism now, and cheeky with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I am... Together... I said it ... and get out of my car at the corner here... I don't have the time to go 'round the block. Anna pulls into the curb. Hector leans over to embrace her before she has stopped the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks... for the car... everything...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do the best you can with them, Hector... and one more thing... deliver these... She indicates a massive bouquet of flowers wrapped in cellophane, taking up the whole of the luggage space in the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?   Anna, I can't...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's the address... just two blocks before the bridge... a five minute detour. It's a golden wedding... you have to... She looks him straight in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to help each other... Hector accepts this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you'll need gas too... Go to it, Hector... She kisses him quickly, but lovingly. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .        * 152   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phone if there's any disasters... don't suffer alone... Hector watches Anna stride, in her business-like way, around the corner OUT OF SIGHT. He is almost home. 153   INT./EXT. CAR - DAY                                         153 A trip from Queens to New Jersey at five o'clock on a Friday afternoon is going to look like a dream sequence whatever you do with it, and that's fine. Hector's trip to his children has more meaning for us than a simple journey from A to B. We will be aware of our other Hectors, and the journeys home that they did or didn't manage to make. This car trip will pull the threads together. And after so many images of the natural world, a world little altered by man, the PANORAMIC SHOTS of New York in all its mad glory will place our Hector in a new dimen- sion. If there is a breathtaking moment in this film, when everything comes together, when all the pieces fit, then it will be somewhere around here that it happens. Six thousand years ago we left Hector on a beach, aching for his family. If the traffic allows, tonight in New Jersey Hector will complete his journey. We will GO WITH Hector OVER the bridge, ACROSS the avenues of Manhattan and THROUGH the tunnel. His PHONE RINGS ONCE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello... Leonard, hello... yes... we're insured... thank God... yes now I know God's a lawyer... thanks... On the outskirts of Jersey City he finds the suburban street he is looking for. If the last crosslight holds on green then he might even make it on time. Hector stops the car outside Janet's house and lets out a sigh of relief. 154   EXT. HOUSE - EVENING                                        154 Hector's former wife, JANET, and her new husband, DONALD, come out of the house as Hector walks up to the door. Donald is carrying luggage and heads straight for their car in the driveway. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 154   CONTINUED:                                                      154 DONALD Hi, Hector. He starts loading up the car.       Janet talks to Hector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You made it. The kids are just coming. They're not over the moon about going to the beach house. I ought to warn you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you say? I could have fixed up something else. I thought it would be a good place to get to know them again...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I figured you should be                            * allowed to make your own mistakes. It's only for a couple of nights, they can take it... and you'll learn... Check into a hotel if it gets too much... they like hotels. She shouts into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, you two... your father's ready to go... She hands Hector a piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is where we'll be, if anything crops up... thanks for the break... Hector gets a little scared about what he has taken on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe this is a bit sudden for them... Maybe I should have come over a couple of nights and got to know them... Janet doesn't let him off the hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By Monday, you'll know them... Then the children come out of the house, BETSY, who is about thirteen, and TOM, who is eleven. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 154   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here he is, the invisible dad. She turns to Hector.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what they call you. Hector is daunted by how grown up they are, not any more the little kids in the photograph in his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. They hardly lift their heads to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Janet takes control of the farewells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You three have a good weekend. If it's too miserable at the house your father said he'll take you to a hotel. Hector nods his head obediently. He always did with Janet. The children let their mother pat them and follow Hector to his car, eyes to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck, Hector. Donald shouts from behind the wheel of his car, where he has been hiding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you Monday, Hector. The kids load themselves into the back of Hector's car. Betsy notices the huge arrangement of flowers, wrapped in cellophane and red ribbon. It seems to have grown even larger than before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are those for mom? Hector looks at the flowers.       His face contorts in guilt and anxiety. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 154   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no... Jesus save me... what have I done...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong? He picks up his mobile phone and is about to dial Anna's number, then he stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... I can't face it, not just now... He looks at the kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go. 155   INT./EXT. CAR - DUSK                                         155 They are driving on the freeway. It is dusk. Hector is on the telephone again. He can't let go of business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, kids... I have to consult the oracle... He gets connected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello... God? No, Leonard, it's Hector... just a joke... sorry to phone you at home, did Boris call you? The insurance is fine? Good ... but she could claim negligence ... oh, she's got a lawyer already? That's a bad omen... Betsy and Tom are listening in the back seat, eager for clues about this virtual stranger in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there anything we can do right now... make her an offer... Sure, with the insurance company... sure... you're right... me, too... I have the kids in the car with me right now... sorry to bother you... 'bye... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 155   CONTINUED:                                                       155 Hector throws the phone onto the passenger seat, lets out a sigh, and catches sight of the kids in the mirror. Their perplexed expressions make them look younger than they are, and vulnerable. Hector's heart aches for them. He smiles and puts on an act of brightness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it! The last call... the weekend starts right now... we have things to do... look out for a Safeway... we need some supplies... and gas... oh my God, gas... soon... They return his look with blank expressions.        He picks up the phone and offers it to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to make any calls?    Betsy? She shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... and it's Thomas...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we called you Tom... that's what it says on your birth certificate...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I changed it. Hector wisely lets it go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right... it's your name... you                            * can do that... Safeway... keep your                       * eyes skinned... and I could murder                        * a Chicken McNugget.                                       * 156   INT. SAFEWAY - NIGHT                                           156 Hector is pushing a cart around a large Safeway. The place is almost deserted. Betsy and Thomas are tagging along. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 156   CONTINUED:                                                      156 For every four items Hector puts in his cart Betsy removes three and returns them to the shelf. Hector notices and puts up with it for a while. But when Betsy returns the rolls of kitchen towel he has selected he makes a stand. He turns to face her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong with that? It's a kitchen roll... why can't I pick a kitchen roll? Betsy is defiant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's bleached... and it isn't recycled... you don't care... you just buy junk... She picks up a more friendly brand of kitchen towel from the shelf and throws it into the cart. Hector has the sense to back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good point, Betsy... Betsy keeps on the attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything you buy is junk... I don't eat steak... and what's this... She prods a packet of frozen hamburgers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ugh! Why don't you ask us what we like... it'll save you money... you buy junk, we won't eat it... A trace of girlish common sense has crept into her voice. Hector warms to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. Hector pushes the cart to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, get to it... I'll just tag along... Betsy moves off with the cart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do it every week anyway. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 156   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas backs her up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She does. She tells us what to eat. We let her. Hector follows them up the aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I just keep a couple of those steaks? We can't live on chicken.                   * 157   EXT. GAS STATION - NIGHT                                   157 Hector is filling up the car in a gas station close to the Safeway. An attractive woman is filling her car in the next line. Her eyes and Hector's meet. For some reason they exchange the smallest smile. For a few brief moments they are talking without words as their tanks fill. The ten billionth romance in the history of the planet sparks into life and fizzles out again in the twinkling of an eye. By the time their credit cards are back in their pockets their love is a memory. From the back of the car the kids have watched it all. Betsy gives Hector a withering look of disapproval as he climbs back into the car. 158   INT./EXT. CAR - NIGHT                                      158 Back on the road, it is later. The kids have fallen asleep. Hector relaxes. He watches them in their sleep, searching for some traces of the little children that have haunted his thoughts for so many years, the tots he abandoned. 159   EXT. HOLIDAY HOUSE - NIGHT                                 159 The car pulls up at the holiday house. Hector gets out. It is dark, but we can hear the sound of the SEA and there is sand underfoot. Hector walks to the house and unlocks the door. He puts on a couple of exterior lights. He carries Thomas, still sleeping, from the car and into the house. Betsy follows him, still half-asleep, groaning fussily. She talks through her yawns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going to bring the flowers in?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't mention the flowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 160   INT. HOUSE - NIGHT                                         160 Later, Hector can't sleep. It has been too eventful a day. He sits bleary-eyed watching a late-night TV SHOW. A man sits cross-legged on a studio floor and is talking to a phone-in viewer. The TV man has five small stones which he regularly scatters on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is good, Tony, the stones are talking to me already... now here's something... travel... movement... Tony, are you planning a move... travel... anything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I am... I've been thinking about a move to California...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The big one, eh, Tony? These stones are really talking here... what are you planning for yourself in California?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm hoping for an acting career, Mel...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tony, these stones really like what you're planning... there is no doubt in my mind about that... now listen... you have to be specific... these stones really want to tell you something, be it love, money or the purpose of your life... but I want a specific question from you... think about it... what do you want to know... love... or your income level next year? Be as specific as you can, Tony... Perhaps this might have enthralled one of our earlier Hectors, but our modern one is simply restless. He stands up and leaves the room. 161   INT. HOUSE - NIGHT                                         161 Next door, he watches the kids sleeping in their little holiday beds. Hector watches them. We've seen our Hectors do this before, and we feel the echo. But as he turns to leave the room Hector gets a fright. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 161   CONTINUED:                                                      161 Betsy starts talking loudly. At first Hector thinks she is awake, giving him into trouble, but she is fast asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get me the books... all the books... all of the books... no, no, no... not the pancakes... not the pancakes... no... She changes in an instant from a bossy adolescent to a tearful, crumpled little girl. She sobs pitifully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... not the pancakes... Hector is a confusion of feelings: frightened, fascinated, impotent. How can he help her? How could he possibly unravel the secret of the pancakes, what comfort could he offer his stranger daughter if he did? It is a spooky, mystical moment for Hector, more mystical than the mumbo-jumbo still issuing from the TV next door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... find your true cosmic partner first time around... every weekday morning at three here on the Psychic Network... Lucinda's Horoscope Dating Show... remember there is an answer, and there is a special partner out there for you... Hector moves quietly out of the room, Betsy's sobs having subsided. Just as he is closing the door he gets another surprise, this time from the sleeping Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... don't let the oil run out... yes you did... watch the oil... why... why? Hector closes the bedroom door.     He is one spooked, moved human being. 162   INT. HOUSE - MORNING                                          162 In the morning, they are making breakfast in the kitchen. The kids are having juice and cereal. Hector is scrambling some eggs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about some eggs? They shake their heads. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 162   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't eat eggs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many have you got in there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three.   Is that all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a week, maybe. Hector does a little probing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about pancakes, Betsy... d'you like pancakes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not much... why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wondered. Pancakes don't mean much to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't mean a thing.     Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. The mystery of Betsy's pancake dream is evidently lost in infinity. Hector changes the subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought we could walk into town this morning. I saw the Funfair when we came through last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't go to Funfairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's take the walk anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I brought some books.   I want to stay home and read. Hector is determined to make it work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   We're taking a walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 163   INT. HALLWAY - DAY                                         163 They are preparing to leave the house.   Thomas is still reluctant to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's going to rain... we should stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's an umbrella... and there must be some old coats in here... and shoes... I only have these I'm wearing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donald has some shoes... Thomas is already in the cupboard under the stairs.   He emerges with a pair of sturdy walking shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know if I want to wear Donald's shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Hector declines to explain the complex   reasons that he might have for not wanting to wear the   shoes of his children's replacement father. He sits    down on the            * stairs to put them on. Then something    on the wall catches his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow.   Look at this. The kids' heights have been marked on the wall on some long-ago holiday. The dates are beside them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six years ago. Look at that... What's this? He points to a mark and a date lower down on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was the flood. The sea came right up. Donald says it's the icecap melting. It's going to get worse. That's why Mom's selling the place. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 163   CONTINUED:                                                      163 HECTOR It comes up every year?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last two. 164   EXT. BEACH - DAY                                               164 They are on the beach, walking in the direction of town. Hector strides ahead in a show of enthusiasm, although awkward in Donald's big shoes. The kids trail behind. He calls back to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are the birds?    Is it the wrong time of year?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't come over so much. The shellfish have gone... that's what...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what Donald says?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... and it happens to be true. Hector looks at the sky.       He speaks quietly to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please don't rain... please... 165   EXT. FUNFAIR - DAY                                             165 The light DRIZZLE now falling is keeping away what few                * fun-seekers there are left in town. The Funfair is not much fun. It is the end of the season. Hector and the                 * kids are a sorry sight parading the empty alleys. The kids seem to glory in the misery of it all, getting back at Hector for four years of neglect. Heavy-hearted, Hector still tries to make a go of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's have a ride... He has stopped at some dated space rockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The seats are wet. Hector triumphs. He pulls a wad of kitchen roll from his pocket and starts to wipe the seats. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 165   CONTINUED:                                                     165 HECTOR Kitchen roll, unbleached, re-cycled, biodegradable... dry seats... Betsy has the grace to smile as the three of them climb aboard the rockets. As the attendant releases the brakes and cranks them up into the drizzle, 'round and 'round, Hector knows that he has to do something to break the awful distance between him and his kids. He looks at them. They sit grimly in their rockets, one in front of him and one behind. Their faces are set in expressions of what? Boredom? Resignation? Patience? Expectancy? Then he realizes what is going on. They are waiting for him to open up to them, talk to them seriously, explain himself. He looks at Betsy's face and sees in it the years of his absence, her stoicism, her patience, her courage. It moves him. He leans over to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is ridiculous. Let's go somewhere and talk. Betsy smiles her small patient smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, if you want to... Hector looks to Thomas. Thomas vigorously nods his agreement. Hector is happier. He looks down on the decrepit fairground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do we land these things? 166   INT. COFFEE SHOP - DAY                                       166 The only place the small town has to offer is a deserted coffee shop on the shorefront. Hector, Betsy and Thomas sit at a corner table, beyond them through the window is the beach and the ocean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you won't have a pancake,                          * Betsy?                                                  * Betsy gets impatient.                                                *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!                                                     * (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 166   CONTINUED:                                                       166 HECTOR Okay, first question?                                     * The kids are ready for this.        There is no coyness now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where have you been?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What he means is why did you stay away? Hector begins like a story-teller embarking on a long saga.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's a fair question... your mother and I got divorced... you're big enough to remember... she must have told you all that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure she has... but lots of people get divorced... that doesn't mean they disappear...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right... what can I tell you... I went kind of crazy after that, for a good while... I came around a few times... remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it wasn't easy... everything with her and Donald happened pretty quickly. I missed you both really badly... but for a while I thought I should stay away, until your mother got settled... no, that's not really true... I missed you... but I was kind of crazy at the same time... your mother and I married young... I wasn't used to the freedom... it went to my head ... then you moved to New Jersey. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 166   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's forty minutes away on a slow bus...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right, you're right. I don't have too many excuses for the first year... the second year is easier... I was in jail. Hector is pleased with this.       A solid excuse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We were doing government work, big contracts... there were some temptations... my boss asked me to shuffle a few papers... there was a lot of money in it... I had to testify against him... it was like killing somebody. Hector thinks about this, remembering the pain. For us there is the echo of the real killing that was done long ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas wanted to visit you in jail, but Mom wouldn't let him.                        * Hector looks at Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did? Thomas nods proudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I appreciate that... but I'm glad your mother didn't let you. I'll tell you all about it some day.  It was no fun. One year and eight months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We didn't even know when you got out. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 166   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't in great shape... I sure didn't want you to see me then... so I got back to work... in real estate... found a partner, we met                      * in jail...                                             * The kids look shocked at this.                                      *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. He's a good man, a good man.                       * I like him. I mean it. He's my                         * friend.                                                *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what you do now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. We rent apartments... but we want to get into commercial property... people are a nuisance... does that sound bad? Betsy shrugs her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How should I know? Hector carries on with his story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just recently I've been feeling good, things have been going well... and I missed you two... so here we are...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about your girl friend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who told you about her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna... she's nice... she wants to meet you, real soon... she sells flowers... well, you know that... and on Monday she's probably going to kill me... The kids smile. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 166   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betsy thinks that was her at the gas station...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, Tom... Hector has to think to remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... heck... no... did you think she was following us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's always thinking up stories like that... she never stops...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if people don't tell you things...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's right, Thomas... people should talk more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you haven't been staying away because of us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean? Is that what you thought? I was avoiding you two? No... you mustn't think that... that's terrible... They have almost exhausted themselves in this first bout of talking. Hector looks out at the sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rain's off. Let's go. 167   EXT. BEACH - DAY                                              167 Betsy and Hector are sitting on the sea wall, watching Thomas play on the beach. The sun is emerging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to ask you something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 167   CONTINUED:                                                     167 BETSY Why did you leave just two days before my swimming test? Hector is moved by the depth of her memory, her pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't leave because it was two days before your test... it was just what your mother and I decided... I taught you how to swim... we went to the pool twice a week... why would I leave?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know... that's what I mean... why did you leave just then? Hector looks at Betsy. She is beginning to cry silently. He puts a tentative arm around her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, God, Betsy. I'm sorry. Betsy is still crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't matter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you do, in the test?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I passed. Hector leaves his limp arm on her shoulder. It is too                * soon for gestures of emotion. After a long moment she speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a life-saver now. Hector doesn't make the obvious comment. His emotions are full. He hides his feelings in a gruff call to Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Thomas! We're going home... we're having a barbecue... Betsy said she'll even let me eat a steak!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry up, Tom!                                          * (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 167   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas breaks off from his play and runs towards them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't call him Tom, he doesn't like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm allowed. Somehow Hector is touched by this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother said it, when we split up... don't lose the children... didn't mean much at the time. But she was right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who said I'd let you eat a steak? There is a silence.      Then Hector speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Betsy.    On Monday will you come with me   when I take the flowers back to   Anna? I can't face her alone.    She wants to meet you anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be there, right beside me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd have to take the morning off school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that bad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, that could be good... Betsy and Hector are quite close now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just tell them you were with your invisible dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .        * 168   EXT. BEACH - DAY                                             168 Hector and Betsy are walking on the shore.     Thomas tags along behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's she like? How did you meet her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The funny thing is I fell in love with her before I ever saw her... I smelled her... It was the day I got out of jail... I was on the train and she was sitting behind me... it was just this incredible perfume... remember I'd been inside for nearly two years with four hundred sweating males... She got off the train and I followed her... I couldn't help it... that's how good she is... she listened to a bum who followed her off a train... Betsy looks at him kindly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... but she's still going to kill me on Monday... They share a laugh.   Betsy looks out to the ocean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I'll paint the sunset tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's just like a big pancake up there, isn't it? Betsy doesn't take the bait.   There is a silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember when you two were tiny.. I used to watch you sleeping... it was like now... I felt close to you, could touch you... but you weren't there... you were gone... dreamland ... just when I was closest to you, you weren't there... I felt it last night, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what it's like... you should know that. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 168   CONTINUED:                                                     168 HECTOR I'm not smart about things like that, usually.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be so tough on yourself. You seem to want to be... you don't have to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... we can do that... She smiles. Hector is out of his depth with this daughter of his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that a joke?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I mean it... look out for yourself... Hector looks at her in wonderment. One of those moments when another human being stands before you and is an utter mystery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?   Who's inside there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll never know. Future generations of women are going to be just as unknowable to our Hectors as past ones were. Betsy moves off briskly along the beach. Hector trails after her, hooked. 169   EXT. BOAT - DAY                                              169 Betsy and Thomas are in a small fragile rowboat, some distance from the shore. They are watching Hector who is collecting a pile of large stones on the beach. Another Hector and another pile of stones. This one is making a fire for the barbecue. These human rituals never stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought he was taller. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 169   CONTINUED:                                                        169 THOMAS Well, it's been a while... you're bigger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose so. He's getting fat, too. I bet I could beat him at the breast-stroke now. 170   EXT. BEACH - DAY                                              170 Hector turns from his work. Out at sea the kids look small and vulnerable. Hector is more anxious than he should be, out of practice at fatherhood. He calls to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on in, kids... that boat doesn't look too safe... They call back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're fine! Hector tries to relax, but he doesn't have the confidence yet, or something. He is edgy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've just found you... I don't want to lose you. What would I tell your mother... come on in... He walks down to the water. The kids reluctantly pull on the oars and bring the little boat in. A few feet from the beach they hit some sand. The boat sticks. Hector wades out in his shoes so far. Then he calls to Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throw me the rope, Thomas, I'll pull you in. Thomas throws the mooring rope to Hector. It isn't attached to the boat. Hector ends up with all of the rope in his hands. He stands there, and they all laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is one useless piece of rope, Thomas... Just for a moment we have the image of our     Hector standing on the shoreline with a length of     rope. An image with an echo from six thousand years     ago. But this time Hector is laughing, and his kids     are safe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .         * 171   EXT. BEACH - SUNSET                                          171 At the very moment of sunset Betsy is trying to capture it in a watercolor sketch. She has set up an easel on the beach. It's like action painting. She works frantically on the picture, racing the sun as it dips into the ocean. Tough little Betsy can even lose patience with the sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why does it always go so fast...? Thomas is laughing at her. He has seen    her attempt this before. Hector has other concerns. He     is trying to light his barbecue. Match after match    disappears into his elaborate stone structure, only to   fizzle out. The sun finally vanishes, and Betsy goes limp at her easel. The sun has won the race again. She and Thomas watch Hector trying to light the fire. After a while he is conscious of their amused attention on him, then he becomes a little self-conscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to know how to do this... They laugh a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did... I used to be really good at this... He wafts and blows ineffectually at a flicker of flame. There's not much of the caveman about him now. 172   EXT. BEACH - DUSK                                            172 It is a calm dusk. Hector is turning the meat on the barbecue. He is in a splendid frame of mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah... smell it... the smell of civilization... scorched meat... Hector serves the chicken onto their plates. He sits down beside them with his steak, and a glass of wine. He watches Thomas attack his chicken, and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd forgotten that... how you eat... dedicated... like it's your religion!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Things I like. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 172   CONTINUED:                                                      172 HECTOR You used to hum to yourself too, when you ate... like everything was fine with the world. Thomas tries it out, eating and humming. It feels good to him. His head nods with the chewing and the tune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, so I did... I'd forgotten about that... The early stars are appearing in the sky. Hector lifts his eyes to a bright point low on the horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There she is... old Mercury...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... Mercury doesn't rise 'til after midnight... that's Jupiter... Hector is impressed by his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd forgotten... we used to watch                        * the stars... you could tell me the                       * names of all the planets... you                          * could recite them like a poem... remember... at the tiny window upstairs in the old house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh well, not to worry. I'm glad you still like astronomy though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not into star-gazing so much ... we're working on computer modelling... we're trying to make a biosphere...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A self-sustaining life system... for inter-stellar travel. But we always get a methane build up, it doesn't matter what we do... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .       * 172   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is at school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. We're making such a mess of the world, one day we're going to have to take off for somewhere else...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds like Donald said that... Hector realizes how far his kids have travelled from him. He looks at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm glad you two are thinking about the old planet. I'm proud of you. Look how beautiful everything is. Sometimes I think it's people that make it all wrong... we walk around with all our problems... Betsy chimes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. If it wasn't for us there'd be nobody around to see it all. Hector stands to fetch another baked potato from the fire. We see the three of them in a WIDE SHOT, the evening sky now pulsing with more and more points of light. Hector's voice and laughter carry to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, you two... I'll tell you... it's just a big, black sheet up there with holes in it so the light comes through... that's the truth... the very latest... Hector has come to rest, and found peace at last, however temporary, here on the beach, beneath the same stars that our first Hector wailed at six thousand years ago. On Monday he will face the music. The kids will go back home, Mrs. Philippopolis will have to be dealt with, and the wilting three hundred dollar bouquet of flowers. In general, life will take over, on Monday. But at this moment of calm on the beach, let's leave him while he's ahead. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 172   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their voices ring out playfully across the expanse of darkening beach and light-laden sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute... I know... the whole universe is inside a speck of dust that's lying in a ball of fluff in the cuff of a pair of pants hanging over the back of a chair...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... I'll tell you... the whole thing... stars and everything... is sitting on the skin of a bubble of milk in a bowl of cornflakes... and somebody's just about to eat it... The three of them are laughing now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Skimmed milk...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't get bubbles in skimmed milk...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay... it's half-and-half... Perhaps that's just about as close as Hector and his                * tribe of humans will ever come to working it all out. But they try.                                                       *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got a better one... we're all inside a speck of pollen that's stuck to the wing of a bee while it sits on a flower...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't mention flowers, Betsy... please, not tonight. And then, after a long, long pause.                                 *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have an idea, Betsy... we're                         * inside a pancake... what d'you                         * think?                                                 * (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 172   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you always talking about                     * pancakes... what's wrong with you?                   *
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got pancakes on the brain.                    *
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The little Girl starts to go back for a precious toy she has dropped. Hector picks her up and carries her off over his shoulder. The Boy follows. Deirdre is trailing behind them. She was right. She doesn't have the stamina for the hill. Hector looks back and sees the Raiders gaining on her. His face is a con- fusion of fear and indecision. He almost stops, as if to go back and help her, but then changes his mind and runs off once again with the children. Deirdre is by now throwing the things she is carrying at her pursuers, hoping that they will stop to retrieve them and allow her to gain some ground. But they don't stop and the effort tires her even more. She attempts one final dash and then, all of her energy gone, she stops in her tracks and waits for her pursuers. the Raiders break their run also and trot and finally walk, the distance between them and Deirdre. Hector is watching all of this over his shoulder, still running. He stops for a moment to watch Deirdre being finally surrounded by the Raiders. Then he runs on. 9    EXT. VALLEY - DAY                                          9 Hector is tiring, too. With the Girl still awkwardly clinging to his neck he is picking his way up a steep slope, half-dragging the Boy up behind him. He stops for a breath and sees the raiders moving into the valley below. In a moment of utter panic he lets go of his son, drops the Girl from his shoulder, and runs on alone. We can sense the moment of release in his unburdened flight. But it doesn't last long. Some way up the slope he stops and turns. He sees his children, only now beginning to work out what has happened, and the raiders below. He can't do it. Even as the Girl calls to him he is running back down the hill, feeling the first stab of a guilt that will never leave him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then he reaches up for the Girl, catches her as she drops and keeps her in his arms. He laughs in a comforting way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then the tense moment passes, as the man grunts and nods at Hector's hands, still bound with rope. Hector under- stands. He lifts his hands and the man with some effort hacks through the rough hemp. Then he turns and wades back to the boat. As the man clambers aboard the Leader speaks to him. The man stops, drops back into the water, and returns to Hector on the shore. He offers Hector the cut piece of rope, a weird gesture of conciliation. He even smiles. Hector refuses the gift. The man stands sheepishly for a moment, then drops the rope at Hector's feet and wades back to the boat. A piece of rope in exchange for a family. Hector watches them for some time, his family and the strange Raiders, as they, achingly slowly, retreat from his view and his life. At last he turns and moves up from the shoreline. He goes some distance then stops, thinks for a moment, then retraces his steps. He goes back to the water's edge, picks up the piece of rope that bound him, and walks off with it. It might be of some use to him. 19   INT. CAVE - DAY                                            19 Hector has returned to his cave home, now cold and empty of life. He is working on his instincts now, still emotionally in shock. He digs around in the embers of the fire. Some of the larger bits of wood still hold some life. Hector bends low and starts to waft expertly
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The other two peer over his shoulders. Suitably mysti- fied, Lucinnius talks in a reverent low voice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: looks up at Lucinnius and Hector, but they offer him no help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For all his wit and endless talk we can sense a trace of vulnerabililty in Ronald. For all his bluster, there is the feeling that he needs Hector as much as he claims Hector needs him. 59   EXT. FARMYARD - DAY                                            59 Overnight, the remnants of a company of soldiers, fresh
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it all feels oddly familiar to us, then perhaps it is the memory of a picture in a forgotten story book, or an ancient landscape on a gallery wall. Once again in the film there is the tantalizing feeling of awaking not from a dream, but in a dream. The moment passes in the more down to earth concerns of Hector and Beatrice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The more we see     of the people, their costumes, weapons, mannerisms, the     easier we will place them in their time. They are
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hector works his oar with the rest. He has time to cast a glance at Ursula and Francisco. Francisco in his manic-heroic way manages to row while at the same time trying to offer a steadying arm to Ursula. If Hector had time or energy to laugh, he would. The raft is in the full rage of the surf. The sense behind its loose construction is obvious now. Snake-like it rides the waves, one half up, the other down. The beaching isn't easy. A few people are washed overboard with no way of saving them. Finally the raft makes it through the barrier of the outer surf. They are in a long curving bay. Up from the beach lies an area of
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some of the survivors have   recovered sufficiently from the trauma of near death to   mark out the boundaries of their new beach homes with   lines of stones. The habits of ownership die hardest of   all. Although Dom Paulo is the man in authority he is also a man in deep shock. Most of what he has earned or plundered in his colonial years now lies at the bottom of the ocean. Since he is socially superior to anyone else on the ship he assumes responsibility and command. There are probably fifty men among the survivors more suited to lead them to safety. By Dom Paulo's side always is his SON. A quiet boy of about eleven. He is like a little miniature of his father, dressed in the same style of clothes. He is a constant, silent witness to everything that Dom Paulo does, good or bad, wise or foolish. He and his father are a continuing fascination for Hector, and we can enjoy Hector watching the boy watching his father. Some of the absurdities and comedies of the situation can be high- lighted in this way. There can be sadness in it too however, the pain of a son witnessing his father's compromises or failures all too closely, and Dom Paulo's sad awareness of his image slowly tarnishing in his son's eyes. Amidst the construction work, Dom Paulo is talking with some of his OFFICERS.
dialogue.name: dialogue
